instructions.title: $a^{2}$ or $a^{3}$
instructions.body: Use the D and A (square) or K (cube) scales.

animation.label: Calculate $2.3^{3}$: Place the cursor at $2.3$ on the D scale
Read 12.2 on the K scale.

instructions.title: $\sqrt{a}$ or $\sqrt[3]{a}$
instructions.body:
Use the D and A ($\sqrt{a}$) or K ($\sqrt[3]{a}$) scales.

Note:
    For square roots, use the left half of the A scale for numbers between 1 and 10 and use the right half for those between 10 and 100.
For numbers outside this range, shift 2 decimal places at a time to get into the range, removing 1 decimal place from the answer for every shift of 2 on the input.

    For cube roots, use the left third of the K scale for numbers between 1 and 10, the middle third for those between 10 and 100, and the last third for those between 100 and 1000.
For numbers outside this range, shift 3 decimal places at a time to get into the range, removing 1 decimal place from the answer for every shift of 3 on the input.

animation.label: Calculate $\sqrt[3]{14}$: Place the cursor at $14$ on the K scale
Read 2.41 on the D scale.
Calculate $e^{-0.20}$: Place the cursor at $2.0$ on the D scale
Read the answer $0.819$ on the LL02 scale (with a range from $-0.1x$ to $-1.0x$)

instructions.title: $a^{b}$
instructions.body:
Use the C, D and L scales.
Equation Used: $a ^ {b} = 10 ^ {\text{log}(a) \times b}$

Note:
    The L scale produces the $\textit{Mantissa}$: the fractional portion of a logarithm
To know the true value of the logarithm, subtract the amount of decimal places of the largest digit place from the mantissa. 
log$(25) = 1 + $log$(2.5)$, log$(0.52) = -1 + $log$(5.2)$

animation.label: Calculate $23.2^{1.8}$:    Place the cursor at $2.32$ on the C scale
Read $0.365$ on the L scale
Note that since the L scale only provides the mantissa of the logarithm, the logarithm is actually $1.365$
Move the cursor to $1.365$ on the D scale
Move the index of the C scale to the cursor
Place the cursor at $1.8$ on the C scale
Read $2.457$ on the D scale
Move the cursor to $0.457$ (mantissa of $2.457$) on the L scale
Read $2.87$ on the C scale. Because we cut a $2$ from $2.457$, we shift $2$ places to get $287$ as our final answer

instructions.title: ln($a$)
instructions.body:
Use the C, D, and L scales.
Equation Used: ln$(a) = \text{log}(a) \times 2.303$

Note:
    The L scale produces the $\textit{Mantissa}$: the fractional portion of a logarithm
To know the true value of the logarithm, subtract the amount of decimal places of the largest digit place from the mantissa. 
log$(25) = 1 + $log$(2.5)$, log$(0.52) = -1 + $log$(5.2)$

animation.label: Calculate ln$(31.4)$: Place the cursor at $3.14$ on the C scale

Note that since the L scale only provides the mantissa of the logarithm, the logarithm is actually $1.497$
Move the cursor to $1.497$ on the D scale
Move the index of the C scale to the cursor
Place the cursor at $2.303$ on the C scale
Read the answer $3.447$ on the D scale

instructions.title: log($a$)
instructions.body:
Use the C and L scales.

Note:
    The L scale produces the $\textit{Mantissa}$: the fractional portion of a logarithm
To know the true value of the logarithm, subtract the amount of decimal places of the largest digit place from the mantissa. 
log$(25) = 1 + $log$(2.5)$, log$(0.52) = -1 + $log$(5.2)$

Note that since the L scale only provides the mantissa of the logarithm, the logarithm is actually $1.497$

instructions.title: log$_{b}$($a$)
instructions.body:
Use the C, D, and L scales.
Equation Used: log$_{b}(a) = \frac{\text{log}(a)}{\text{log}(b)}$

Note:
    The L scale produces the $\textit{Mantissa}$: the fractional portion of a logarithm
To know the true value of the logarithm, subtract the amount of decimal places of the largest digit place from the mantissa. 
log$(25) = 1 + $log$(2.5)$, log$(0.52) = -1 + $log$(5.2)$

instructions.title: sin($\alpha$)
instructions.body:
Use the D and S or ST scales.

Note:
    For angles less than 5.74°, use the ST scale. Use the S scale for angles between 5.74° and 90°.
    For cosine, use the italicized numbers on the S scale.

animation.label: Calculate sin($23°$): Place the cursor at $23$ on the S scale
Read 0.391 on the D scale.

instructions.title: csc($\alpha$)
instructions.body:
Use the DI and S or ST scales.

Note:
    For angles less than 5.74°, use the ST scale. Use the S scale for angles between 5.74° and 90°.
    For secant (1/cosine), use the italicized numbers on the S scale.

animation.label: Calculate csc($23°$): Place the cursor at $23$ on the S scale
Read 2.56 on the DI scale.

instructions.title: tan($\alpha$)
instructions.body:
Use the D and T or ST scales.

Note:
    For angles less than 5.71°, use the ST scale. Use the T scales for angles between 5.74° and 90°, using the <45° and >45° scales appropriately.
    For cotangent, use the italicized numbers on the T scale.

animation.label: Calculate tan($23°$): Place the cursor at $23$ on the T scale
Read 4.24 on the D scale.

instructions.body: Use the C and CF scales.

instructions.title: min & sec
instructions.body:
Use the ST and D scales.

Note:
    The tick marks on the ST scale are used to convert minutes (') and seconds ('') into radians.

Move the index of the slide to the cursor
Move the cursor to the minutes mark (') on the ST scale
Read 0.0122 radians on the D scale.
